results.title: Other planets: no place like Earth (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bert Shapiro, Lothar Wolff, National Educational Television and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
This film summarises the knowledge that scientists have gathered about the planets, covering such subjects as the seasonal changes on Mars, the atmosphere of Venus, the motion of Jupiter, the rings of Saturn, the discoveries of Neptune and Pluto. Through computer animation, viewers are taken on a “grand tour” of the outer planets (Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune) simulating a trip actually planned for an unmanned space ship in the late 1970s.

results.title: The Lopsided wheel
results.creator_credit: Bedrick Rogers, L. Richard Ellison and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
The development of the wheel is illustrated from its invention to its use in computer machinery. Wheels of all kinds are shown and their common relation to certain laws of energy. This film highlights the problems created by wheels in the United States and other industrialised nations where there are too many, and in underdeveloped countries where there are not enough.

results.title: After the whale
results.creator_credit: L. Richard Ellison and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
Probably the most misunderstood animal, the whale is shown in this film to be a playful, shy, browsing mammal, defenceless against us and on the verge of extinction.

results.title: How to read biographies
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Literature Appreciation”.
Shows how biographies may help in understanding history through the use of recreations from a number of biographies and autobiographies. Insights into the characters and philosophies of famous men and women are also given.

results.title: How to Read Poetry

results.title: Analysing characters
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Literature Appreciation”.
Literary characters of James Thurber, Bret Hart and Nathaniel Hawthorne some to life to explain themselves, and appear in dramatisations of famous stories. They rate themselves in terms of development and complexity, and invite judgement of their actions based on each author’s purpose in writing their story.

results.title: Literature Appreciation
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: How to read plays
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Literature Appreciation”.
The suggestions in this film for reading a play emphasise imaginative reconstruction of the stage production, thus enabling the reader to grasp the visual, aural and dramatic content of a play from the written page.

results.title: How to Read Novels

results.title: How to read essays
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Literature Appreciation”.
Such great writers as Lamb, Hunt Addison, Thackeray and Steveson, who produced political and humorous as well as philosophical essays, are portrayed at work in their native surroundings. The film emphasises that for full appreciation an essay should be read with an understanding of the author, their purpose and their style.
